_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Cargill Meat Solutions - Wyalusing, PA primary business is processing wholesale distribution of meat products for human consumption. The facility operates an ammonia refrigeration system as part of the process to keep products and raw materials fresh. 40 CFR 68.130 lists anhydrous ammonia as a hazardous chemical subject to RMP regulation with a threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs. The refrigeration system inventory exceeds the 10,000 lb. threshold.  Ammonia is recirculated in the system as a liquid and gas depending on system operating pressures and temperatures.  



The RMP was updated in September 2017 to meet the 5 year RMP resubmission criteria. The overall quantity onsite was increased to reflect more accurate methods to calculate the worst case and normal operating quantities onsite. There was not processing or plant expansion that took place which would have increased the total onsite quantity. Rather, the methodologies used for inventory calculations improved and are reflected now in the RMP revision. 



Facility release modeling was performed using EPA's modeling program RMP*Comp in addition to ALOHA software. The methodologies reported in CDX reflect conservative modeling approaches to meet the endpoint criteria. 



The Wyalusing facility as two independent machinery rooms for ammonia refrigeration systems. The machinery rooms are called Plant 1 and Plant 2 respectively in the report and CDX processes. 



For Plant 1, the worst-case scenario is based on the High Side as that vessel could potentially hold the largest quantity of ammonia. No passive or administrative controls were considered for the release scenario. 



For Plant 1, the alternate release scenario was a pressure relief device on the High Side Accumulator lifting. This device was selected since it was the highest rated capacity for a relief device. No passive or administrative controls were considered for the release scenario. Other alternate cases were considered, including vessel overf

illing, over pressurization scenarios, pipe ruptures and material handling and transfer hoses. 



For Plant 2, the worst-case release scenario is based on the Control Pressure Receiver as that is the largest vessel in Plant 2 capable of holding the largest quantity of ammonia. No passive or administrative controls were considered for the release scenario. 



For Plant 2, the alternate release scenario is based on the Pilot Receiver having a leak on a pipe since it is located outdoors and operates at the highest pressure relative to all other vessels in Plant 2. No passive or administrative controls were considered for the release scenario. Other alternate cases were considered, including vessel overfilling, over pressurization scenarios, pipe ruptures and material handling and transfer hoses. 



The facility has developed and implemented a Process Safety Management Program (PSM) in accordance with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119.  The facility's PSM program includes provisions for process hazard analyses, training, standard operating procedures, management of change, pre-start up safety reviews, safe work practices, inspections, testing, maintenance, compliance audits, and contractor qualifications. All significant changes to the system are reviewed in accordance with the PSM/ RMP management of change provisions in the facility's plan. Qualified outside contractors are used for construction and major repairs or modifications to the system. The facility has an emergency action plan in place and conducts periodic response drills and coordinates with the local fire department and LEPC. The facility is committed to continually improving safety through program implementation and execution. The facility has not experienced a release incident that meets the EPA's 5 Year Accident Reporting criteria involving ammonia that resulted in any on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or that resulted in any off

site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. 



The system is equipped with a series of redundant failsafe devices, sensors, and overrides. In the event a malfunction occurs that could result in an ammonia release, these protective devices shut the system down. The system can't be restarted until the cause of the shutdown is identified and corrected.  The Plant 1 and Plant 2 system shutdown can be manually operated using a switch located outside the engine room.
